text: A triple-mutant rat ANP, rANP(G16R,A17E,Q18A) [rANP(REA18)], retains full NPR-A agonist potency (cGMP ED50 ≈ 1.8 nM) but shows ~200-fold reduced binding to the clearance receptor NPR-C. In conscious rats, rANP(REA18) produces greater natriuresis (and a trend toward greater diuresis) than wild-type rANP at doses yielding the same blood-pressure lowering, consistent with NPR-C acting as a decoy that limits renal NPR-A effects.
source_paper_title: Novel analog of atrial natriuretic peptide selective for receptor-A produces increased diuresis and natriuresis in rats.

text: In insulin receptor–deficient (insulin-resistant) mice, an n‑3 fatty acid diet markedly reduced arterial LDL uptake and cholesteryl ester deposition—including selective LDL‑CE uptake—compared with a saturated fat diet. This reduction tracked with a shift in arterial lipoprotein lipase from high levels throughout the aortic media (saturated fat) to LpL largely confined to the intima (n‑3), linking n‑3–induced lowering of arterial LDL-cholesterol delivery to altered arterial LpL level/distribution.
source_paper_title: n-3 Fatty Acids Decrease Arterial Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol Delivery and Lipoprotein Lipase Levels in Insulin-Resistant Mice

text: Diet-induced vitamin D deficiency in C57BL/6 mice suppresses baseline colonic antimicrobial defenses—specifically reducing angiogenin-4 expression/protein—and is accompanied by ~50-fold higher bacterial levels in colonic tissue even before colitis is induced. This impaired bacterial containment predisposes the mice to more severe DSS colitis (greater weight loss, higher colitis scores, splenomegaly), implicating dysregulated antimicrobial activity as the mechanism linking low vitamin D to colitis susceptibility.
source_paper_title: Vitamin D Deficiency in Mice Impairs Colonic Antibacterial Activity and Predisposes to Colitis

text: This abstract does not report a single novel experimental finding; it describes a review that summarizes recent progress in developing functional allosteric modulators of metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs). The main takeaway is that selective mGluR allosteric modulators have emerged as promising therapeutic candidates across multiple CNS disorders (e.g., anxiety/depression, schizophrenia, epilepsy/stroke, pain, and neurodegenerative diseases).
source_paper_title: Molecular Pharmacology and Therapeutic Prospects of Metabotropic Glutamate Receptor Allosteric Modulators

text: Cord blood mononuclear cells cultured with genetically modified K562 cells expressing membrane-bound IL-15 and 4-1BB ligand (K562-mbIL15-41BBL) achieved an approximately 35-fold expansion of NK cells within 7 days, increasing the CD56+/CD3− NK cell population from 3.9% to 71.7% of total cells. This expansion was significantly greater than that achieved with wild-type K562 cells (42.6%) or antibody/cytokine cocktail stimulation (33.9%), while simultaneously reducing T cell percentages, thereby minimizing graft-versus-host disease risk.
source_paper_title: Genetic Engineering and Significant Ex-Vivo Expansion of Cord Blood Natural Killer Cells: Implications for Post-Transplant Adoptive Cellular Immunotherapy

text: Oral 2-methoxyestradiol (2-ME), a microtubule-disrupting endogenous estrogen metabolite, inhibits cytokine-driven angiogenesis in vivo—reducing bFGF- and VEGF-induced corneal neovascularization by 39% and 54%, respectively—and suppresses human breast carcinoma growth in SCID mice by 60% without detectable toxicity. Among microtubule inhibitors tested, only 2-ME and Taxol showed in vivo antiangiogenic activity, whereas vincristine and colchicine did not.
source_paper_title: Inhibition of angiogenesis and breast cancer in mice by the microtubule inhibitors 2-methoxyestradiol and taxol.

text: A plasmid cleavage-based screening platform using dual positive and negative selection was developed to identify Cas9 or gRNA variants with improved targeting specificity. Preliminary results demonstrate that a gRNA containing an insertion in the scaffold region of the RNA reduces off-target cleavage, suggesting this platform can successfully identify novel RNA variants with enhanced fidelity compared to the naturally occurring CRISPR components.
source_paper_title: 340. Development of a Nuclease Screen to Improve Cas9 Targeting Specificity

text: Targeting full-length ErbB-2 DNA to the cytoplasm for rapid proteasomal degradation (cytE2/cytE2A), especially when co-delivered with GM-CSF or IL-2 DNA, protected mice from ErbB-2+ mammary tumor challenge as effectively as wild-type ErbB-2 vaccination but without inducing anti-ErbB-2 antibodies. This protection was mediated by ErbB-2–specific CD8+ CTLs (CD8 depletion abrogated immunity), consistent with enhanced peptide presentation from cytoplasmic ErbB-2.
source_paper_title: Vaccination with Cytoplasmic ErbB-2 DNA Protects Mice from Mammary Tumor Growth Without Anti-ErbB-2 Antibody

text: Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) was successfully used to treat an infected sternal dehiscence (deep sternal wound infection) after cardiac surgery in a patient who did not respond to conventional management. This case suggests VAC can be an effective alternative for complex post-sternotomy infections when standard debridement/packing/irrigation and delayed closure approaches fail.
source_paper_title: Vacuum-assisted closure to treat deep sternal wound infection following cardiac surgery

text: A PEG-thiol–coated colloidal gold nanoparticle vector with surface-bound recombinant human TNF (PT-cAu-TNF) selectively and rapidly accumulates in MC-38 colon carcinoma tumors after intravenous injection while showing little to no uptake in RES organs (liver/spleen) or other healthy tissues. This tumor-specific sequestration delivers TNF more effectively and with reduced systemic toxicity, achieving maximal antitumor effects at lower TNF doses than native TNF.
source_paper_title: Colloidal Gold: A Novel Nanoparticle Vector for Tumor Directed Drug Delivery

text: Photoaffinity mapping combined with NMR-guided docking shows that VIP binds the VPAC1 N-terminal ectodomain via specific contacts between VIP Phe6, Tyr22, and Asn24 and receptor residues Asp107, Gly116, and Cys122, respectively. The resulting model places VIP residues 6–28 along the C-terminal part of the ectodomain while leaving the VIP N-terminus unbound and available to engage the transmembrane region, providing structural support for a two-step activation mechanism in class II GPCRs.
source_paper_title: Peptide Agonist Docking in the N-terminal Ectodomain of a Class II G Protein-coupled Receptor, the VPAC1 Receptor

text: In established renovascular hypertension models (one- and two-kidney Goldblatt rats and chronic coarctation dogs), renal denervation attenuates hypertension without altering renin activity or sodium excretion, but in association with reduced overall sympathetic nervous system activity. This implicates renal *afferent* nerves as a causal driver of renovascular hypertension by reflexly enhancing systemic sympathetic outflow, rather than via classic efferent renal mechanisms.
source_paper_title: Renal nerves in the pathogenesis of hypertension in experimental animals and humans

text: FcRn-mediated IgG transport is functional in the lungs of non-human primates and can be exploited to achieve systemic absorption of erythropoietin when Epo is fused to an IgG1 Fc domain. A recombinant “monomeric-Epo”–Fc (single Epo linked to a dimeric Fc) delivered predominantly to FcRn-rich upper/central airways showed enhanced PK/PD and lung bioavailability approximately comparable to subcutaneous unconjugated Epo in humans, demonstrating noninvasive pulmonary delivery of a bioactive protein in therapeutic quantities via FcRn.
source_paper_title: Pulmonary delivery of an erythropoietin Fc fusion protein in non-human primates through an immunoglobulin transport pathway

text: Recombinant *Listeria monocytogenes* engineered to stably express and secrete the LCMV nucleoprotein—or even just the H-2Lᵈ–restricted nucleoprotein epitope (aa 118–126)—acts as an effective live vaccine that protects mice from otherwise chronic, virulent LCMV infection. This protection is mediated by CD8⁺ T cells, since in vivo CD8⁺ T-cell depletion abolishes viral clearance in vaccinated animals.
source_paper_title: Recombinant Listeria monocytogenes as a live vaccine vehicle for the induction of protective anti-viral cell-mediated immunity.

text: In patients after acute coronary syndromes, adding ezetimibe to statin therapy further lowered LDL cholesterol and led to improved cardiovascular outcomes compared with statin therapy alone. The abstract also indicates that achieving LDL levels below prior guideline targets conferred additional clinical benefit.
source_paper_title: Ezetimibe Added to Statin Therapy after Acute Coronary Syndromes

text: Genome sequence analysis using an Fc receptor (FcR) consensus identified a previously unrecognized, closely linked subfamily of five Fc receptor homolog (FcRH) genes at chromosome 1q21. FcRH1–3 encode type I transmembrane Ig-superfamily glycoproteins with multiple Ig-like extracellular domains and cytoplasmic immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activating and/or inhibitory motifs, and the FcRH genes are expressed primarily by mature B-lineage cells—implicating this new multigene family as potential regulators of B-cell development.
source_paper_title: Identification of a family of Fc receptor homologs with preferential B cell expression

text: In *Methanocaldococcus jannaschii*, **l-lactate used for 2-phospho-*l*-lactate (coenzyme F\(_{420}\) biosynthesis) is produced not from pyruvate but by NAD\(^+\)-dependent oxidation of *l*-lactaldehyde catalyzed by the MJ1411 gene product (lactaldehyde dehydrogenase)**. The required *l*-lactaldehyde is generated either by NAD(P)H-dependent reduction of methylglyoxal or by MJ1418 (fuculose-1-phosphate aldolase)-mediated aldol cleavage of fuculose-1-phosphate.
source_paper_title: Identification of Lactaldehyde Dehydrogenase in Methanocaldococcus jannaschii and Its Involvement in Production of Lactate for F 420 Biosynthesis

text: In a ~5–10% subset of sporadic ALS patients, elevated serum IgM antibodies against oxidized SOD1 (SODox) are associated with markedly longer survival (~6.4 years) compared with patients lacking these antibodies, suggesting a protective immune response to aberrantly modified SOD1. Conversely, higher IgG reactivity to normal wild-type SOD1 is associated with shorter survival (~4.1 years), implying that immunity to native SOD1 may be detrimental.
source_paper_title: Anti-superoxide dismutase antibodies are associated with survival in patients with sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

text: Molecular cloning from human liver mRNA revealed two distinct cDNA forms encoding the G\(_s\) α-subunit: a full-length α\(_{s2}\) and a variant α\(_{s1}\) that lacks a specific 42-nucleotide segment (nt 214–255). This deletion produces an α\(_s\) protein shorter by 14 amino acids and introduces two adjacent amino-acid substitutions (Asp for Glu and Ser for Gly) at the deletion junction, providing the first evidence that α\(_s\) structural heterogeneity can arise from differences in amino-acid sequence.
source_paper_title: Identification by molecular cloning of two forms of the α‐subunit of the human liver stimulatory (G<sub>s</sub>) regulatory component of adenylyl cyclase

text: Nitric oxide bidirectionally regulates membrane lipid peroxidation: at low NO relative to superoxide/H2O2/•OH flux it enhances oxidation via formation of secondary oxidants such as peroxynitrite, whereas at higher NO flux it inhibits both ROS- and peroxynitrite-driven lipid peroxidation by directly scavenging lipid alkoxyl/peroxyl radicals and terminating chain propagation. This inhibition is accompanied by formation of novel nitrogen-containing oxidized lipid adducts (nitrito-, nitro-, nitrosoperoxo-, and nitrated derivatives), without evidence for iron–lipid–NO complex formation.
source_paper_title: Nitric oxide regulation of superoxide and peroxynitrite-dependent lipid peroxidation. Formation of novel nitrogen-containing oxidized lipid derivatives

text: The FVIII-mimetic activity of the asymmetric anti-FIXa/FX bispecific antibody ACE910 is strongly governed by non–antigen-contacting structural elements, especially the tertiary structure imposed by inter-chain disulfide bonding. Specifically, IgG4-like HC–LC disulfides (HC Cys131–LC Cys114) together with hinge-region HC–HC disulfides are indispensable for high activity, and increasing hinge/Fc flexibility (upper-hinge proline mutations and Fc glycan removal) further enhances the FVIII-mimetic function.
source_paper_title: Non–antigen-contacting region of an asymmetric bispecific antibody to factors IXa/X significantly affects factor VIII-mimetic activity

text: Surface plasmon resonance (Biacore) and bridging ELISA detect different anti-panitumumab antibody populations: despite lower analytical sensitivity and poorer drug tolerance, the Biacore assay identified far more clinical immunogenicity (4.1% vs 0.3%) and more neutralizing responses (8 vs 1) than ELISA. This divergence is explained by affinity bias—ELISA preferentially detects higher-affinity antibodies (even with high drug excess), whereas Biacore is more sensitive to lower-affinity antibodies and can detect them under higher drug-to-antibody ratios.
source_paper_title: Comparing ELISA and Surface Plasmon Resonance for Assessing Clinical Immunogenicity of Panitumumab

text: Conditional loss of TGF-β type II receptor signaling in mammary stromal fibroblasts (Tgfbr2 fspKO) promotes mammary carcinoma progression by increasing fibroblast-derived growth factors (HGF, MSP, TGF-α), which activates their receptors (c-Met, RON, erbB1/erbB2) in tumor cells and drives greater tumor growth, angiogenesis, survival/proliferation, and intravasation. In contrast, deleting TβRII in mammary carcinoma cells did not support a required role for tumor-cell TGF-β signaling in invasion/metastasis in this model.
source_paper_title: Hypoxia promotes invasion and metastasis of breast cancer cells by increasing lysyl oxidase expression

text: A polyoma virus–based plasmid (pMGD20neo) containing the PyF101 origin and expressing only polyoma large T antigen can replicate autonomously and be stably maintained as a nonintegrated episome in mouse embryonic stem cells, persisting at ~10–30 copies per cell for at least 74 generations under G418 selection with no detectable genomic integration for ≥28 generations. ES cell lines carrying this episome retain normal karyotype and can still generate chimeric mice, indicating episomal maintenance and large T expression do not abolish developmental competence.
source_paper_title: Maintenance of an extrachromosomal plasmid vector in mouse embryonic stem cells.

text: Short, highly cationic 12‑mer peptides (notably PTD‑4 and PTD‑5, as well as polylysine/polyarginine) function as protein transduction domains, delivering an avidin–β‑galactosidase cargo into many primary and transformed cell types with efficiencies comparable to HIV TAT and ~600‑fold above a random peptide control. These PTDs drive intracellular accumulation in both cytoplasm and nucleus and enable rapid in vivo protein delivery into rabbit synovium and mouse solid tumors after local injection.
source_paper_title: Characterization of a Class of Cationic Peptides Able to Facilitate Efficient Protein Transduction in Vitro and in Vivo

text: **Oligonucleotide-directed random mutagenesis can be achieved by spiking each phosphoramidite used in oligonucleotide synthesis with a mixture of the other three bases, generating randomized oligonucleotides.** These spiked oligonucleotides are then employed in the phosphorothioate-based in vitro mutagenesis method to produce a library of random mutants, extending site-directed mutagenesis approaches to genes where detailed structural information is lacking.
source_paper_title: Oligonucleotide-Directed Random Mutagenesis Using the Phosphorothioate Method

text: In a double-blind RCT of mildly to moderately depressed adults, 12 weeks of EPA+DHA supplementation (1.5 g/day) produced no meaningful improvement in depressed mood versus placebo (DASS depression 8.4 vs 9.6; adjusted difference −1.0, 95% CI −2.8 to 0.8; P=0.27) and similarly did not affect other mood or cognitive outcomes. When combined with prior trials in a meta-analysis, the result supported an overall negligible benefit of n-3 LCPUFA supplementation for depressed mood.
source_paper_title: No effect ofn-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acid (EPA and DHA) supplementation on depressed mood and cognitive function: a randomised controlled trial

text: A pyrosequencing-based mtDNA assay was developed that targets selected polymorphic sites in both the mitochondrial D-loop (including HVI/HVII) and coding region to maximize discrimination power while minimizing the number of bases that must be sequenced. When tested on control samples and real forensic casework materials, this panel produced fast, easily interpretable mtDNA profiles with high accuracy, sensitivity, reproducibility, and a high success rate.
source_paper_title: Mitochondrial Sequence Analysis for Forensic Identification Using Pyrosequencing Technology

text: The authors introduce Event-wise Testing (EWT), a read-depth–of-coverage CNV detection method that tests the significance of candidate deletion/duplication intervals (with multiple-testing control) rather than segmenting the genome point-by-point. Applied to 30× paired-end shotgun data from five individuals (chromosome 1), EWT detects CNVs effectively and captures structural variants—such as large insertions and variants in complex genomic regions—that are difficult to detect with paired-end mapping–based approaches.
source_paper_title: Sensitive and accurate detection of copy number variants using read depth of coverage

text: The 2.5 Å structure shows that the KSHV ENE does not merely bind the uridine-rich internal loop; instead, the poly(A) tail engages both the loop and the lower stem to assemble an RNA triple helix. This triple-helix sequestration of the poly(A) tail provides a structural mechanism for blocking initiation of RNA decay and thereby stabilizing the viral noncoding RNA.
source_paper_title: Poly(A) Tail Recognition by a Viral RNA Element Through Assembly of a Triple Helix

text: Across 169 nasopharyngeal swabs, the study directly compared the analytical performance of a CDC-primer–based laboratory-developed RT-PCR test with four FDA EUA commercial SARS‑CoV‑2 assays (Cepheid, DiaSorin, Hologic Panther, and Roche Cobas), providing head-to-head performance data that had been largely lacking. The abstract does not report the comparative results (e.g., sensitivity/specificity or agreement), only that the comparison was performed.
source_paper_title: Comparison of Commercially Available and Laboratory-Developed Assays for In Vitro Detection of SARS-CoV-2 in Clinical Laboratories

text: In anesthetized dogs, an intravenous cocaine bolus produced a clear dose-dependent escalation of electrocardiographic toxicity: 1 mg/kg caused mainly sinus bradyarrhythmias and isolated ventricular ectopy, 2 mg/kg provoked more severe supraventricular (including atrial flutter/fibrillation) and ventricular arrhythmias, and 5–7 mg/kg prolonged ECG intervals with ST-segment elevation and triggered sustained ventricular tachycardia progressing to ventricular flutter/fibrillation and death.
source_paper_title: Electrocardiographic Effects of Intravenous Cocaine: An Experimental Study in a Canine Model

text: GLABRA3 (GL3) encodes a maize R–like bHLH regulator that controls Arabidopsis trichome development by forming protein complexes with GLABRA1 (GL1) and TRANSPARENT TESTA GLABRA1 (TTG1). Yeast two-hybrid assays show GL3 physically interacts with GL1, TTG1, and itself, whereas GL1 and TTG1 do not interact, implying GL3 is the bridging component in a combinatorial regulatory complex.
source_paper_title: GL3 Encodes a bHLH Protein That Regulates Trichome Development in Arabidopsis Through Interaction With GL1 and TTG1

text: Specific periodontal pathogens (including *Porphyromonas gingivalis*) can significantly invade human primary coronary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells, as shown by antibiotic protection assays and electron microscopy. This invasion requires host-cell actin polymerization and eukaryotic protein synthesis, and intracellular *P. gingivalis* localizes within multimembranous vacuoles resembling autophagosomes.
source_paper_title: Invasion of Human Coronary Artery Cells by Periodontal Pathogens

text: During rapid, experimentally induced glucose excursions in intensively managed diabetics, dermal interstitial fluid glucose measured from suction blisters closely tracked both capillary and venous blood glucose with high correlation. Importantly, no significant time lag was detected between interstitial fluid and blood glucose changes, indicating near-synchronous dynamics across these compartments under rapid fluctuations.
source_paper_title: Comparison of Glucose Concentration in Interstitial Fluid, and Capillary and Venous Blood During Rapid Changes in Blood Glucose Levels

text: **Membrane vesicle (MV) release is a universally conserved process across all domains of microbial life—bacteria, archaea, fungi, and parasites—sharing similar visual, mechanistic, and functional features, including the use of ESCRT proteins and their homologues.** Despite this conservation, the cross-kingdom parallels in MV biogenesis and function (including delivery of toxins, enzymes, immune antigens, and signaling molecules) have been largely overlooked and underappreciated in the literature.
source_paper_title: Membrane Vesicle Release in Bacteria, Eukaryotes, and Archaea: a Conserved yet Underappreciated Aspect of Microbial Life

text: In 13-day chick embryo aorta, lysine residues incorporated into elastin are oxidized within ~1 hour and then rapidly converted into the mature elastin crosslinks desmosine and isodesmosine during the next hour, with radiolabeled desmosine/isodesmosine detectable as early as 1 hour into the chase. This indicates that elastin crosslink formation from newly incorporated lysine is essentially completed within ~2 hours, while more poorly crosslinked elastin accumulates in soluble fractions and lysine-derived crosslinking is also present in the microfibril fraction.
source_paper_title: Synthesis of Elastin. A Rapid Formation of Lysine-derived Crosslinks by Chick Embryo Aorta

text: A zero-linker, reversed-orientation anti-CD22 scFv (V_L–0–V_H) unexpectedly self-assembled into homogeneous noncovalent dimers that were substantially more stable than the conventional V_H–5–V_L diabody in human serum at 37 °C and remained dimeric even when concentrated to 4 mg/ml. This identifies V_L–0–V_H as a particularly stable multivalent format for targeting CD22+ tumor cells.
source_paper_title: Antigen binding and stability properties of non‐covalently linked anti‐CD22 single‐chain Fv dimers

text: Klebsiella pneumoniae dihydroxyacetone kinase is a distinct, highly DHA-specific dimeric enzyme (Km ~4 µM) that neither uses nor is inhibited by glycerol (even at 100 mM) and is not allosterically inhibited by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, unlike E. coli glycerol kinase. Its biochemical distinctness is supported by immunology: antibodies to E. coli glycerol kinase cross-react with K. pneumoniae glycerol kinase but not with K. pneumoniae DHA kinase.
source_paper_title: Purification and properties of dihydroxyacetone kinase from Klebsiella pneumoniae

text: Human pancreatic cancers commonly overexpress VEGF (≈5.2-fold higher VEGF mRNA than normal pancreas; strong VEGF immunoreactivity in 64% of 75 tumors), and VEGF-positive tumors have increased microvessel density. VEGF expression correlates with larger tumor size and enhanced local spread (local disease progression) but not with reduced patient survival.
source_paper_title: Enhanced expression of vascular endothelial growth factor in human pancreatic cancer correlates with local disease progression.

text: AMOLED displays can be fabricated using backplanes made from transfer‑printed microscale silicon integrated circuits (instead of conventional TFTs), with the ICs printed onto glass and interconnected via a single‑level thin‑film metallization process. This approach produced OLED displays with good pixel‑to‑pixel luminance uniformity, high luminance, excellent control, and a transfer‑printing process demonstrating high positional accuracy and yield.
source_paper_title: 63.2: AMOLED Displays Using Transfer‐Printed Integrated Circuits

text: Sufficiently concentrated polyelectrolyte solutions can be used for layer-by-layer self-assembly because the adsorbed polyelectrolyte does not bind all its ionic groups to the surface, leaving free charges at the film/solution interface that reverse (or restore) the surface charge and enable the next adsorption step without requiring rigid charge separation. Using alternating adsorption of oppositely charged bipolar amphiphiles and polyelectrolytes, the authors build stable multilayer films of at least 39 alternating layers (≈151 nm total thickness).
source_paper_title: Buildup of Ultrathin Multilayer Films by a Self‐Assembly Process: II. Consecutive Adsorption of Anionic and Cationic Bipolar Amphiphiles and Polyelectrolytes on Charged Surfaces

text: Variation in the gut microbiome is a crucial determinant of immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) efficacy, with xenograft and patient evidence indicating that specific commensal bacteria can enhance antitumor responses to ICIs. The abstract proposes that the gut microbiome can serve as a predictive biomarker and that deliberately manipulating it may increase ICI response rates.
source_paper_title: Gut microbiome modulates efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors

text: Daily carbamylated erythropoietin (10 μg/kg) during 10 days of severe chronic hypoxia (6.5% O₂) reduced hypoxia-induced metabolic stress and apoptosis without affecting hemoglobin, survival, or weight loss, showing a tissue-protective effect independent of erythropoiesis. Specifically, CEpo prevented the chronic hypoxia–driven rise in neuronal HIF‑1α and Epo receptor–associated stress immunoreactivity and lowered neuronal apoptotic index, while also reducing myocardial apoptosis despite no hypoxia-induced myocardial HIF‑1α increase.
source_paper_title: Carbamylated erythropoietin ameliorates the metabolic stress induced in vivo by severe chronic hypoxia

text: The abstract’s central finding is that **blocking tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) is clinically effective for treating Crohn’s disease**, a Th1-driven condition marked by elevated IL-12, TNF-α, and IFN-γ. It also highlights that **anti-TNF therapy carries notable risks**, including immunogenicity/infusion and hypersensitivity reactions, autoimmune complications (e.g., drug-induced lupus, demyelination), and infections.
source_paper_title: New concepts in anti-tumor necrosis factor therapy for inflammatory bowel disease.

text: HGF/Met signaling drives breast cancer cell migration through a Brk–ERK5 pathway in which Brk forms complexes with ERK5 and promotes ERK5 activation, yet Brk’s own kinase activity is dispensable for the migratory response. In Brk-null cells, re-expression of either wild-type or kinase-inactive Brk is sufficient to activate ERK5 and restore/enhance HGF-induced migration, implicating Brk/ERK5 complex formation (rather than Brk catalysis) as the critical step.
source_paper_title: Breast tumor kinase and extracellular signal-regulated kinase 5 mediate Met receptor signaling to cell migration in breast cancer cells

text: In 78 critically ill patients admitted with SIRS and suspected infection, procalcitonin (PCT) outperformed IL‑6 and IL‑8 for diagnosing sepsis-related conditions, achieving an AUC of 0.92 and, at a 1.1 ng/mL cutoff, 97% sensitivity and 78% specificity for distinguishing SIRS from sepsis. Adding PCT to standard clinical/laboratory indicators significantly improved diagnostic prediction (AUC 0.77→0.94), whereas IL‑6 and IL‑8 provided no additional predictive value.
source_paper_title: Diagnostic Value of Procalcitonin, Interleukin-6, and Interleukin-8 in Critically Ill Patients Admitted with Suspected Sepsis

text: In a yeast model, loss of the cdk5 orthologue Pho85 unexpectedly drives tau-4R into a hyperphosphorylated, MC1-positive pathological conformation that increases aggregation ~40-fold and yields soluble tau that rapidly forms filaments in vitro. Anion-exchange purification identified a hyperphosphorylated *monomeric* intermediate (hP-tau/MC1) that is structurally stable and potently seeds/accelerates aggregation of wild-type tau-4R, indicating this specific monomer can initiate tau filament formation.
source_paper_title: Identification and Isolation of a Hyperphosphorylated, Conformationally Changed Intermediate of Human Protein Tau Expressed in Yeast

text: Chicken cells expressing transforming, membrane-associated oncogenic Src (pp60^527F) show strong tyrosine phosphorylation of a previously unrecognized ~120-kDa protein (p120), and this phosphorylation tightly correlates with morphological transformation. p120 phosphorylation is absent with nononcogenic pp60^c-src overexpression and is not induced by a transformation-defective, nonmyristylated activated Src variant (pp60^2A/527F), indicating that Src membrane association is required for p120 phosphorylation and transformation.
source_paper_title: Transformation-specific tyrosine phosphorylation of a novel cellular protein in chicken cells expressing oncogenic variants of the avian cellular src gene.

text: GPR30 is uniquely localized to the endoplasmic reticulum and specifically binds estrogen (and fluorescent estrogen derivatives), identifying it as an intracellular transmembrane estrogen receptor. Estrogen activation of ER-localized GPR30 rapidly triggers intracellular Ca²⁺ mobilization and induces nuclear phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate synthesis, providing a mechanism for rapid nongenomic estrogen signaling.
source_paper_title: A Transmembrane Intracellular Estrogen Receptor Mediates Rapid Cell Signaling

text: Human lung mast cells synthesize substantial chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans in addition to heparin proteoglycans, with ~36% of total ^35S-labeled proteoglycans being chondroitin sulfates. Disaccharide analysis showed that these chondroitin sulfates include a previously unrecognized chondroitin sulfate E component, comprising ~25% of the chondroitin sulfate disaccharides (GlcUA–GalNAc4,6-diSO4), and appear to reside on protein cores distinct from the heparin proteoglycans.
source_paper_title: Identification of chondroitin sulfate E in human lung mast cells.

text: Recombinant human tyrosine hydroxylase binds weakly to negatively charged phospholipid bilayers (apparent \(K_d\) ≈ 230–380 μM at pH 6.0–7.0) via its N‑terminal region, likely involving two amphipathic N‑terminal α‑helices, since proteolysis reduces binding affinity. This membrane association decreases TH enzymatic activity while stabilizing α‑helical structure against thermal denaturation without major changes in overall secondary structure, consistent with amphitropic regulation.
source_paper_title: The binding of tyrosine hydroxylase to negatively charged lipid bilayers involves the N‐terminal region of the enzyme

text: In TrkB-overexpressing neuroblastoma xenografts, the Trk-selective inhibitor lestaurtinib significantly inhibited tumor growth and improved event-free survival, and it markedly potentiated the antitumor efficacy of standard chemotherapy regimens (topotecan/cyclophosphamide and irinotecan/temozolomide). This enhancement is attributed to blockade of the Trk/brain-derived neurotrophic factor autocrine survival pathway, whereas adding retinoids provided no additional benefit and combining with bevacizumab, despite strong growth inhibition, caused substantial systemic toxicity.
source_paper_title: Lestaurtinib Enhances the Antitumor Efficacy of Chemotherapy in Murine Xenograft Models of Neuroblastoma

text: A 6‑month hypocaloric diet plus moderate physical activity program producing ~6.9 kg weight loss in insulin‑resistant obese adults significantly improved insulin sensitivity and lowered circulating leptin and IL‑6 (with a trend toward lower TNF‑α). Leptin reductions correlated with decreases in BMI and highly sensitive C‑reactive protein, while adiponectin rose significantly only in participants with diabetes.
source_paper_title: Effect of Lifestyle Modification on Adipokine Levels in Obese Subjects with Insulin Resistance

text: Nrf2 knockout mice develop experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) with earlier onset, greater incidence, and more severe clinical disease than wild-type mice. This exacerbation is accompanied by increased spinal immune-cell infiltration and glial activation, along with elevated expression of inflammatory enzymes (iNOS and NADPH oxidase subunits), proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ, IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-12), and chemokines (BLC, MIG), indicating that Nrf2 normally restrains autoimmune neuroinflammatory responses.
source_paper_title: The Absence of the Pro-antioxidant Transcription Factor Nrf2 Exacerbates Experimental Autoimmune Encephalomyelitis

text: The HER2-selective tyrosine kinase inhibitor TAK-165 suppresses growth of HER2-expressing urological cancers, showing in vivo xenograft tumor growth inhibition in bladder (UMUC3), kidney (ACHN), and androgen-independent prostate (LN-REC4) models after 14 days of oral dosing (T/C 22.9%, 26.0%, and 26.5%, respectively). Despite relatively weak HER2 expression in these lines, TAK-165 produced measurable in vitro cytotoxicity—particularly in androgen-independent prostate cancer cells (IC₅₀ 0.053–4.62 µmol/L).
source_paper_title: Novel HER2 selective tyrosine kinase inhibitor, TAK‐165, inhibits bladder, kidney and androgen‐independent prostate cancer in vitro and in vivo

text: End-stage failing human left ventricles show opposite regulation of the two intracellular Ca²⁺-release channels in cardiac myocytes: ryanodine receptor (RyR) mRNA is reduced by 31% while inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (IP3R) mRNA is increased by 123%, with a ~40% rise in IP3 binding sites relative to ryanodine binding sites. This shift suggests diminished RyR-mediated Ca²⁺ release with a compensatory increase in IP3R-mediated Ca²⁺ mobilization in failing myocardium.
source_paper_title: Differential regulation of two types of intracellular calcium release channels during end-stage heart failure.

text: **Platelet aggregation and secretion require the native triple-helical structure of collagen, whereas monomeric and fibrillar collagens are sufficient to support platelet adhesion.** Using CNBr-peptide mapping, three aggregatory sites were identified in the α1(I) chain and one in the α1(III) chain of collagens type I and III, with the highly homologous peptides α1(I)CB3 and α1(III)CB4 being key mediators of platelet adhesion and aggregation, respectively.
source_paper_title: Platelet-Collagen Interactions

text: All-trans retinoic acid treatment induced *post hoc* alveolar septation in two mammalian models where septation had previously failed—glucocorticoid-blocked neonatal rats and adult tight-skin mice with a genetic septation defect—partially restoring alveolar subdivision (smaller, more numerous alveoli with increased surface area). This demonstrates that failed developmental septation can be re-initiated after the normal window for septation has passed.
source_paper_title: Retinoic acid treatment partially rescues failed septation in rats and in mice

text: Melancholic and non-melancholic major depression show distinct cognitive-control profiles: melancholia is marked by attention/working-memory deficits linked to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex function, whereas non-melancholia shows verbal recall deficits consistent with left frontal and medial temporal involvement. Across patients, anxious arousal and psychomotor disturbance predicted cognitive impairment more strongly than overall depression severity or anxious apprehension, implicating these features in poorer dorsolateral prefrontal–related task performance.
source_paper_title: The impact of depression heterogeneity on cognitive control in major depressive disorder

text: Immunotherapies designed to harness antitumor cellular immune responses have now produced sufficiently dramatic and/or statistically significant clinical benefits in large randomized phase 3 trials to meet the oncology community’s acceptance threshold and achieve FDA approval—placing them alongside established cancer treatment modalities.
source_paper_title: Immunotherapy earns its spot in the ranks of cancer therapy

text: Implanting biodegradable polyanhydride wafers loaded with BCNU into the post-resection cavity provided ~3 weeks of sustained local chemotherapy in 21 patients with recurrent malignant glioma and was well tolerated, with no adverse reactions attributable to the wafers and no detectable systemic toxicity on serial laboratory testing. Survival after reoperation was ~64–65 weeks in the two lower-dose groups (overall median 46 weeks postimplant), supporting the feasibility of interstitial BCNU delivery and motivating a placebo-controlled trial to test survival benefit.
source_paper_title: Interstitial chemotherapy with drug polymer implants for the treatment of recurrent gliomas

text: A protein-oriented silver staining protocol was modified to sensitively visualize PCR-amplified HLA-DQA1/DQB1 exon 2 restriction fragments (≈40–200 bp) in polyacrylamide gels, with linear signal intensity over ~8–18 ng of DNA. Coupled with allele-specific RFLP, this enables simple, rapid, and accurate nucleotide-level clinical typing of HLA-DQ alleles without relying on more hazardous detection methods.
source_paper_title: Application of silver staining to the rapid typing of the polymorphism of HLA‐DQ alleles, by enzymatic amplification and allele‐specific restriction fragment length polymorphism

text: Tumor-derived microvesicles reprogram CD14+ monocytes during IL-4/GM-CSF–driven differentiation, blocking dendritic-cell maturation and instead generating CD14+HLA-DR−/low myeloid cells that secrete TGF-β and suppress activated T-cell proliferation and cytolytic function. This T-cell suppression is TGF-β–dependent (reversed by anti–TGF-β antibodies) and is recapitulated by circulating microvesicles from advanced melanoma patients, who also show an expanded peripheral blood subset of TGF-β–secreting CD14+HLA-DR−/low suppressor cells.
source_paper_title: Human Tumor-Released Microvesicles Promote the Differentiation of Myeloid Cells with Transforming Growth Factor-β–Mediated Suppressive Activity on T Lymphocytes

text: Engineering the oncolytic vaccinia virus GLV-1h68 to express a Walker A motif mutant of the DNA-replication factor Cdc6 (GLV-1h237) increased viral replication and cytotoxicity in GI-101A breast cancer cells and produced the strongest tumor regression in GI-101A mouse xenografts after a single i.v. dose. This enhanced anti-tumor efficacy occurred with high tumor selectivity and a safety profile comparable to the parental GLV-1h68.
source_paper_title: Vaccinia virus GLV-1h237 carrying a Walker A motif mutation of mouse Cdc6 protein enhances human breast tumor therapy in mouse xenografts

text: The reviewed internal radiation therapy approaches can selectively target radiation to primary or metastatic hepatic tumors while limiting exposure to the surrounding nontumorous liver. However, the abstract emphasizes that their clinical efficacy remains unproven and requires evaluation in randomized controlled trials.
source_paper_title: Internal radiation therapy for patients with primary or metastatic hepatic cancer

text: Genetically engineered fusions of the anti-ganglioside antibody ch14.18 to human cytokines (IL‑2, GM‑CSF, TNF‑α, TNF‑β) largely preserved both antigen binding (with IL‑2 fusion even enhancing binding) and cytokine bioactivity (except GM‑CSF, ~20% active). However, in mice these antibody–cytokine fusion proteins cleared much faster than the parent antibody due to a very rapid initial (α‑phase) clearance despite similar terminal (β‑phase) half-lives (~30 h vs ~58 h for ch14.18), implying that continuous infusion may be needed for efficacy.
source_paper_title: Biological activity and in vivo clearance of anti-tumor antibody/cytokine fusion proteins

text: The humanized anti-HLA-DR antibody IMMU-114 kills B-cell malignancies (including rituximab-resistant lymphomas, CLL, and multiple myeloma) through hyperactivation of ERK and JNK MAP kinase signaling pathways, a mechanism distinct from anti-CD20 and anti-CD74 antibodies. Critically, HLA-DR surface expression alone is insufficient for cytotoxicity—antibody-induced ERK and JNK hyperactivation is also required, explaining why HLA-DR-positive acute myelogenous leukemia cells are resistant to IMMU-114 despite positive antigen staining.
source_paper_title: Therapy of B-cell malignancies by anti–HLA-DR humanized monoclonal antibody, IMMU-114, is mediated through hyperactivation of ERK and JNK MAP kinase signaling pathways

text: The authors developed “colony hybridization,” a rapid screening method in which E. coli colonies grown on nitrocellulose are lysed and their denatured DNA is fixed in situ, then probed by hybridization to a radioactive RNA to identify colonies carrying a specific gene sequence by autoradiography. Using this approach, they isolated ColE1 hybrid plasmid clones containing Drosophila melanogaster 18S and 28S rRNA genes, demonstrating that any gene represented in an available RNA can be retrieved from large clone libraries.
source_paper_title: Colony hybridization: a method for the isolation of cloned DNAs that contain a specific gene.

text: A fully non-enzymatic microarray probe-prep protocol quantitatively and reproducibly fragments DNA using a hydroxyl radical reaction (H₂O₂/Fe(II)-EDTA/ascorbate) and then densely biotinylates the resulting fragments via a biotinylated psoralen analog plus UVA light. This approach avoids the irreproducible fragmentation, high input requirements, and high labeling costs of existing enzymatic/biotinylation methods, and is validated by successful hybridization on oligonucleotide-coated microspheres and Affymetrix Cancer GeneChip arrays.
source_paper_title: Reproducible and inexpensive probe preparation for oligonucleotide arrays

text: The abstract provided does not describe amino acid biosynthesis inhibitors or herbicidal activity; instead, it summarizes the Hippo signaling pathway as an evolutionarily conserved regulator of tissue growth, cell fate decisions, and organ size. As written, it contains no specific experimental result or mechanistic claim that could be extracted as a single novel finding.
source_paper_title: AMINO ACID BIOSYNTHESIS INHIBITORS AS HERBICIDES

text: Improved understanding of the normal gut microbiota suggests that deliberately manipulating the gut ecosystem could become a feasible and realistic therapeutic strategy in the future.
source_paper_title: The normal intestinal microbiota

text: The authors improved a phase-resolved transversal PS-OCT system for in vivo human retinal imaging (10× faster acquisition at 820 nm; 1000 transversal lines/s), enabling rapid high-resolution B-scans and 3D C-scan datasets. Using this instrument, they report the first in vivo 3D measurements of retinal retardation and fast-axis orientation in the fovea and optic nerve head, allowing layer-specific characterization of polarization/birefringence in the RPE, Henle’s fiber layer, and RNFL.
source_paper_title: Imaging of polarization properties of human retina in vivo with phase resolved transversal PS-OCT

text: An abrupt change in aspect ratio within a single microchannel rapidly destabilizes a confined coflowing dispersed-phase stream, producing highly monodisperse droplets (coefficient of variance <1.5%) even at high dispersed-phase volume fractions (gel emulsions). This enables one-step, in situ generation of gel emulsions in microfluidic devices without the previously required multistep droplet-splitting networks.
source_paper_title: Generation of monodisperse gel emulsions in a microfluidic device

text: This abstract does not report a single new experimental finding; it is a review summarizing existing technologies and membrane-associated protein targets across several cancers. Its main takeaway is that preclinical/clinical results suggest tumor types have distinct, tumor-specific membrane-protein “Achilles heel” targets, so effective diagnosis and therapy require identifying and validating different membrane-associated protein targets for each neoplasm.
source_paper_title: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Use of Membrane Proteins in Cancer Cells

text: In living Nicotiana leaf cells, Golgi stacks move rapidly and extensively *along* the polygonal cortical ER tubules without leaving them, and this motility depends on an actin cable network that mirrors ER architecture (disrupted by cytochalasin D/N-ethylmaleimide). These data support a model in which the plant Golgi operates as motile, actin-directed stacks that travel on the ER to collect cargo from a relatively stationary ER, and they also show in vivo brefeldin A–induced retrograde transport of a Golgi membrane protein back to the ER.
source_paper_title: Stacks on tracks: the plant Golgi apparatus traffics on an actin/ER network†

text: CD22 functions as a sialic acid–binding lectin: a soluble CD22-Ig fusion protein binds multiple lymphocyte sialoglycoproteins in a manner that requires intact sialic acid side chains. This recognition depends specifically on α2,6-linked sialic acids, as CD22 binds a 115-kDa sialoglycoprotein only in cells engineered to express an α2,6-sialyltransferase.
source_paper_title: CD22, a B cell-specific immunoglobulin superfamily member, is a sialic acid-binding lectin.

text: In vivo electroporation can deliver plasmid DNA to living animal tissues with gene-transfer efficiency comparable to or higher than in vivo lipofection, gene gun, or direct DNA injection, while remaining nonviral and amenable to repeated dosing without expected immunogenicity. Although expression is typically transient and episomal, the resulting foreign gene products can persist for over a month (depending on tissue and construct) and can be modulated in a tissue/cell-specific and inducible manner.
source_paper_title: In vivo electroporation: a powerful and convenient means of nonviral gene transfer to tissues of living animals (Review).

text: Six of 14 patients with B cell–negative SCID carried mutations in **RAG1 and/or RAG2**, and these mutations caused a **functional failure of V(D)J recombination**, preventing antigen receptor formation. This identifies **RAG recombinase defects** as a genetic cause of human B− SCID, directly linking impaired site-specific recombination to the disease.
source_paper_title: RAG Mutations in Human B Cell-Negative SCID

text: Using the extreme discordant sib-pair (EDSP) design for QTL linkage mapping, the authors derive sample-size and screening requirements (with adjustment formulas for significance/power and marker density/informativeness) and conclude that, even under this most powerful sib-pair design, a realistically sized study can only detect loci explaining roughly ≥10% of the quantitative trait variance.
source_paper_title: Mapping quantitative trait loci with extreme discordant sib pairs: sampling considerations.

text: CSF beta-amyloid(1-42) and tau levels increased over time across all diagnostic groups in memory clinic patients, while phosphorylated tau at threonine 181 did not change longitudinally. Critically, cross-sectional differences between diagnostic groups far exceeded within-individual longitudinal changes, indicating that these CSF biomarkers lack sensitivity as markers of disease progression.
source_paper_title: Longitudinal changes of CSF biomarkers in memory clinic patients

text: The thioglycerol motif in PAM₂CS-type TLR2 agonists can be replaced with a simpler thioethanol bridge, yielding a structurally simplified, more synthetically accessible, and water-soluble monoacyl lipopeptide analogue that retains strong TLR2-agonistic activity in human blood. Additionally, the study established that at least one palmitoyl (C₁₆) acyl group and a correctly oriented ester carbonyl—maintaining precise spacing from the thioether to enable a critical hydrogen bond observed in the TLR2:lipopeptide crystal structure—are essential for activity.
source_paper_title: Structure–Activity Relationships in Toll-Like Receptor 2-Agonists Leading to Simplified Monoacyl Lipopeptides

text: This abstract does not report a single new experimental finding; it is a review. Its main takeaway is that elucidated mechanisms of NDV-mediated oncolysis and genetic engineering of NDV are enabling the development of novel oncolytic agents, and ongoing clinical trials of NDV strains and NDV-based autologous tumor cell vaccines are expected to advance and support eventual clinical use.
source_paper_title: Oncolytic Newcastle Disease Virus for Cancer Therapy: Old Challenges and New Directions

text: HIV-1 matrix (MA) mutations potently and transdominantly (>100-fold at a 1:1 cotransfection ratio) block infectivity of HIV-1 virions pseudotyped with MuLV Env by preventing HIV-1 protease–mediated cleavage of the MuLV transmembrane protein p15(E) to p12(E), despite normal Env incorporation. The degree of infectivity loss correlates with reduced p15(E) cleavage, and infectivity is rescued when virions are pseudotyped with a truncated p12(E) MuLV Env, indicating that MA controls PR-dependent activation of MuLV Env fusion.
source_paper_title: Cleavage of the Murine Leukemia Virus Transmembrane Env Protein by Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 Protease: Transdominant Inhibition by Matrix Mutations

text: In a human adipocyte cell line, the older HIV protease inhibitor ritonavir—but not the newer atazanavir—impairs adipocyte physiology by inhibiting differentiation, increasing apoptosis, and selectively reducing insulin signaling in mature adipocytes. Ritonavir also shifts adipocytokine output toward insulin resistance by decreasing adiponectin expression while inducing interleukin‑6, providing a cellular explanation for its stronger association with lipodystrophy and metabolic complications.
source_paper_title: HIV Protease Inhibitor‐Specific Alterations in Human Adipocyte Differentiation and Metabolism

text: Long-term coadministration of rifampin with zidovudine markedly reduces zidovudine exposure (lower AUC) by increasing its apparent clearance, while increasing plasma exposure to the metabolite zidovudine glucuronide. In one patient, stopping rifampin doubled zidovudine AUC, supporting that rifampin induces zidovudine glucuronidation and thereby accelerates zidovudine elimination.
source_paper_title: Pharmacokinetic interaction between rifampin and zidovudine

text: This abstract does not report a specific novel experimental finding; it is a general overview. Its central takeaway is that many membrane-associated signaling proteins require covalent lipid modifications for proper membrane localization and function, enabling transmission of extracellular signals across the plasma membrane.
source_paper_title: Protein Lipidation in Cell Signaling

text: Deleting the hCGβ carboxyl‑terminal peptide (CTP) changes how the β subunit’s two N‑linked glycans are processed, specifically altering conversion of the core mannosyl units to complex, polylactosamine-containing oligosaccharides at both glycosylation sites. These posttranslational glycan changes imply that the CTP contributes to folding of newly synthesized hCGβ, thereby influencing its intracellular maturation.
source_paper_title: The Carboxyl-Terminal Region Is a Determinant for the Intracellular Behavior of the Chorionic Gonadotropin β Subunit: Effects on the Processing of the Asn-Linked Oligosaccharides

text: Malignancy promotes thrombosis through both host-wide tumor responses (acute-phase reaction, inflammation, angiogenesis) and direct tumor-cell interactions with coagulation/fibrinolysis pathways and with blood/vascular cells (leukocytes, platelets, endothelium), and this prothrombotic tendency is further amplified by anticancer treatments such as surgery and chemotherapy. These mechanistic insights provide an experimental rationale for thrombosis prevention/treatment in cancer patients and suggest that antithrombotic strategies might also influence tumor growth and dissemination.
source_paper_title: Pathogenetic Mechanisms of Thrombosis in Malignancy

text: In angiotensin II–induced hypertensive mice, pravastatin attenuates left ventricular structural remodeling and diastolic dysfunction via cholesterol-independent (“pleiotropic”) actions that improve/restore endothelial function and reduce vascular inflammation. The abstract further suggests this protective effect may involve ROCK1 signaling.
source_paper_title: Pravastatin Attenuates Left Ventricular Remodeling and Diastolic Dysfunction in Angiotensin II-Induced Hypertensive Mice

text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis VKORH can substitute for human VKORC1 in mammalian cells, supporting vitamin K–dependent carboxylation by reducing either vitamin K epoxide or vitamin K. In this mammalian vitamin K cycle context, the conserved “loop” cysteines (human C43/C51; Mt-VKORH C57/C65) are not required for activity, implying Mt-VKORH switches to a VKORC1-like electron-transfer mechanism in mammalian cells.
source_paper_title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase Homologue Supports Vitamin K–Dependent Carboxylation in Mammalian Cells

text: This abstract is a table-of-contents–style overview of wound-closure biomaterials and devices (needles, sutures, staples/clips, tissue adhesives, and emerging materials) and does not report any specific experimental result or causal finding. As written, it contains no single novel finding to extract beyond the general scope that it reviews inflammatory/wound-healing responses and design/selection principles for closure materials.
source_paper_title: Wound Closure Biomaterials and Devices

text: In vitro–assembled circular maize minichromosomes containing 7–190 kb of centromere-repeat–rich maize DNA plus DsRed/nptII can form autonomous chromosomes in maize that are stably maintained through mitosis and meiosis without selection. These MMCs transmit through multiple generations with near-Mendelian segregation (e.g., 93% as a disome; 39% as a monosome to wild type; 59% in self crosses) while retaining intact, expressed transgenes for at least four generations.
source_paper_title: Meiotic Transmission of an In Vitro–Assembled Autonomous Maize Minichromosome

text: XPG directly interacts with the human thymine glycol DNA glycosylase HsNTH and stimulates its binding to thymine glycol–containing DNA, increasing HsNTH glycosylase/AP lyase activity by ~2-fold in vitro. This identifies a second DNA-repair function for XPG beyond nucleotide excision repair, providing a mechanistic basis for reduced thymine glycol repair in XPG-defective cells.
source_paper_title: Nucleotide excision repair 3' endonuclease XPG stimulates the activity of base excision repairenzyme thymine glycol DNA glycosylase

text: This article does not report a specific novel experimental or mechanistic finding; it is a primer that synthesizes how modern oilseed processing has shifted from stand‑alone unit operations to integrated facilities where each step must account for downstream impacts. Its key contribution is an overview of the typical processes and their interrelations across an end‑to‑end, value‑added manufacturing chain from raw seed to finished products.
source_paper_title: A Primer on Oils Processing Technology

text: The abstract does not report a specific novel experimental or mechanistic finding; it is a methods-focused overview. Its central takeaway is that predicting biomaterial clinical performance requires combining direct molecular-weight/molecular-weight-distribution measurements (via rheology) with relaxation/thermal characterization (DMA, dielectric spectroscopy, DSC) and fracture/fatigue-based reliability prediction, plus shelf-life assessment.
source_paper_title: Advanced Testing Methods for Biomaterials

text: Ionizing-radiation sterilization is becoming a mature, increasingly adopted medical-device technology because it enables faster processing and cost savings, and because EPA restrictions on ethylene oxide exposure are pushing manufacturers to switch to in-house or outsourced radiation sterilization. At the same time, manufacturers are beginning to evaluate alternative sterilants (e.g., chlorine dioxide) and develop nonchemical methods such as plasma sterilization.
source_paper_title: Medical Markets for Radiation Sterilizable Plastics

text: Comparative ELISA profiling of cytokines in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and peripheral blood distinguished active pulmonary granulomatous diseases: primary tuberculosis showed elevated IL‑6 and IFN‑γ in both compartments with increased BAL sIL‑2R, whereas active sarcoidosis showed elevated IFN‑γ and TNF‑α in both compartments with increased serum sIL‑2R. Across these diseases, sIL‑2R tracked the alveolitis (T‑cell activation) phase, while IL‑6 versus TNF‑α preferentially discriminated tuberculosis versus sarcoidosis granulomatous activity.
source_paper_title: Cytokines assay in peripheral blood and bronchoalveolar lavage in the diagnosis and staging of pulmonary granulomatous diseases.

text: ZD1839 (Iressa), a substituted anilinoquinazoline, potently inhibits EGFR tyrosine kinase activity (IC₅₀ 0.033 µM), blocks EGF-stimulated EGFR autophosphorylation, and selectively suppresses EGF-driven tumor cell growth (IC₅₀ 0.054 µM). In multiple human tumor xenograft models, once-daily oral ZD1839 produced dose-dependent tumor growth inhibition and, with >3 months continuous dosing, completely halted growth and regressed established A431 tumors without emergence of drug-resistant tumors; notably, xenograft sensitivity was not determined by EGFR expression level.
source_paper_title: BindingDB Entry 50022499: ZD1839 (Iressa): an orally active inhibitor of epidermal growth factor signaling with potential for cancer therapy.

text: In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, peripheral administration of exenatide (a GLP‑1 receptor agonist) at standard diabetes doses produced positive clinical effects in patients with Parkinson’s disease compared with placebo. This provides human trial evidence that targeting GLP‑1–mediated gut–brain signaling can be therapeutically beneficial in Parkinson’s disease.
source_paper_title: Exenatide once weekly versus placebo in Parkinson’s disease: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial
